translated: YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra, fascicle 54
Expounded by Maitreya Bodhisattva
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on imperial command

In the chapter on the five sense consciousnesses and the mental consciousness in the section on the ascertainment of the essentials, it is said: Next, how is the aggregate of consciousness distinguished?
This should also be understood in five ways.
First, by abiding;
second, by defilement;
third, by support;
fourth, by dwelling;
fifth, by different characteristics.
What is meant by abiding?
It refers to those who indulge in desire, whose consciousnesses in the desire realm grasp external forms and objects,
called the abiding of form and name.
If it is the pure heavens, whose consciousnesses in the form realm grasp internal form and name,
called the abiding of form and name together.
The consciousnesses in the formless realm only grasp internal name,
called the abiding of name.
This is called the distinction in the abiding of consciousness.
What is the distinction in defilement?
It refers to the fact that the consciousnesses of ignorant ordinary beings are defiled through two gates.
First, in the present life, through the door of enjoying objects.
Second, in the future life, through the door of birth, old age, etc.
This is called the distinction of the defilement of consciousness.
What is the distinction of the basis?ğŸ”½It refers to the six bases of consciousness.
It means that the six groups of consciousness arise based on the six sense bases such as the eye.
It is like worldly fire that arises based on husks, cow dung, kindling, etc.
This is called the distinction of the basis of consciousness.
What is the distinction of abiding?
It refers to the four abodes of consciousness.
As the sutra says:
There are four that take clinging as their object, causing consciousness to abide.
It means that consciousness abides following form, taking form as its object.
As explained in the sutra,
I never say that this consciousness goes to the east, or even to the four intermediate directions.
However, I only say that in the present life, one must be free from desire, like a shadow, extinguished, tranquil, cool, and pure.
Thus, the characteristics of the abodes of consciousness taught by the TathÄgata in the sutra have been revealed.
From here on I will proclaim the distinctions of these characteristics.

Namely, this sÅ«tra briefly reveals the characteristics of the abodes of consciousness and the causes and conditions.ğŸ”½The two kinds of limits of the causes and conditions of the abodes of consciousness.
The two kinds of quiescence of the causes and conditions of the abodes of consciousness.
It should be known that among them, if there are the affairs of afflictions,
If they belong to those afflictions,
They are called clinging.
It should be known that these two are also called objects,
Because they are the nature of objects and because they have objects.
Because that craving is the condition for afflictions,
It is called the affairs grasped by the destinies.
Because of the four kinds of fetters of the body such as craving,
It is called the condition for giving rise to karma.
Because those two latent tendencies follow the affairs of the objects,
It is called the established affairs.
If there are ordinary beings,
If they have not yet attained the antidote of detachment and delight,
Because the moistened consciousness can grasp and fulfill the future inner body,
Because of this, it can be passed on to grasp and fulfill,
It cannot abandon the nature of ordinary beings.
Because it can grasp and fulfill within one's own body.
In the process of transmigration, it continues uninterrupted.
This is called abiding.
The other causes and conditions of abiding should be understood as before.
This is called the brief explanation of the characteristics of abiding and its causes and conditions.
Consciousness in the form realm has coming and going.
Consciousness in the formless realm has death and rebirth.
Moreover, these two abidings last until the end of one's life.
Moreover, these two grow, increase, and expand.
This should be understood as before.
This is called the limit of the abodes of consciousness and the limit of the causes and conditions of abiding.
If one were to establish it differently from this,
one should know that there is only a difference in words, not a difference in meaning.
Because the remaining meanings and objects do not exist.
If others rightly question, one does not know what to answer.
It is also because the remaining meanings and objects do not exist.
Or, there may be those who are able to naturally contemplate in accordance with principle later on.
They will then become confused and think, I am foolish and speak like this.
If one is wise, one can completely eliminate and abandon the fetters of craving that are included in craving for form up to craving for volitional formations.
One can also completely eliminate and abandon the four fetters of action that are included in the category of afflictions.
Why is this so?
Because the householders, based on the two fetters of craving and hatred,
give rise to various actions and grasp at objects as their cause.
Because they harm sentient beings as their cause.
If the renunciant, based on the grasping of precepts and vows,
gives rise to various actions due to the two fetters of grasping at this as real.
Because grasping at precepts and vows is like craving, seeking rebirth in the heavens.
Because grasping at this as real is like hatred, slandering nirvÄá¹‡a. One should know that the four fetters arise only from the discrimination in the mental ground.
From this point onward, due to repeatedly cultivating the superior antidotes,
one can completely eliminate and abandon the two kinds of latent tendencies of the fetters of craving.
Because of this elimination, the objects of form, feeling, etc. that are the objects of the afflictions also do not continue.
Because one is completely free from bondage.
Because the objects of cognition do not continue,
The consciousness that is subject to latent afflictions is ultimately extinguished.
It no longer abides in the various abodes of consciousness such as form and feeling.
Because the consciousness of the antidote is permanently pure,
This is called the cessation of the causes and conditions of the abodes of consciousness.
Moreover, because the causes and conditions of the future are extinguished,
One does not grasp or cling to the internal body.
It is certain that there will be no more continuous transmigration.
This is called the cessation of the abodes of consciousness.
Moreover, the pure consciousness that is included in the antidote is called without abode.
Because of those causes and conditions, it is called not growing.
Because one skillfully cultivates the gate of liberation of emptiness,
It is called without activity.
Because one skillfully cultivates the gate of liberation of wishlessness,
It is called contentment.
Because one skillfully cultivates the gate of liberation of signlessness,
It is called abiding.
In this way, because it does not grow,
Up to because it abides,
It is called ultimate liberation.
Moreover, they do not grasp at self and mine in regard to form, etc.
For this reason, when form, etc. is destroyed, they are not terrified.
By this characteristic, their essence is shown to have attained purity.
Moreover, because their consciousness is eternally pure,
without waiting for other causes, they spontaneously enter into quiescence.
Because the continuity of this consciousness is ultimately severed,
it no longer flows and turns in the worlds of the ten directions.
Because they do not hope for life and death,
they are said to be eternally free from desire.
Moreover, all feelings are the shadows of the tree of consciousness.
Since they do not exist at that time,
they are said to be eternally free from shadows.
Because all contaminated consciousnesses are ultimately extinguished in the present life,
they are said to be quiescent.
All uncontaminated consciousnesses, in their respective sequences, are the liberation of learners.
They are said to be tranquil.
The liberation of non-learners
is said to be cool.
Because the remaining supports are eternally extinguished,
it is said to be pure.
Moreover, the intrinsic nature of the various consciousnesses is not defiled.
Because the World-Honored One has said that the nature of all minds is originally pure.
Why is this?
It is not that the intrinsic nature of the mind is ultimately impure and can give rise to faults.
It is also not like all afflictions such as greed, which alone serve as the causes of afflictions like form and feeling.
Why is this?
Because there is definitely no one who gives rise to defiled attachment to the nature of consciousness alone, as they do to form and so forth.
Therefore, only consciousness is not established as a station of consciousness.
This is called the distinction of the aggregates of consciousness based on stations.
What is the distinction of different characteristics?
It refers to a mind with greed, a mind apart from greed, a mind with anger, a mind apart from anger, and so on, as extensively explained in the sutras.
Up to a mind that is not liberated, and a mind that is extremely liberated.
This is called the distinction of different characteristics in one aspect.
There is also the distinction of different characteristics based on realms.
It refers to the four minds in the desire realm.ğŸ”½A wholesome mind, an unwholesome mind,ğŸ”½a mind with hindrances and indeterminate,
a mind without hindrances and indeterminate.
The form realm has three minds.
Excluding unwholesome [minds].
The formless realm has three minds.
Also excluding unwholesome [minds].
The uncontaminated [minds] have two:
The learner and post-learner [minds].
Moreover, wholesome minds in the desire realm are of two kinds.
Namely, those arisen from added effort and those innate.
Unrestricted-unwholesome minds are of four kinds: minds born of retribution,
minds of deportment,
minds of craftsmanship,
and minds of transformation.
These are only innate.
Namely, those of devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, and so forth. However, there are no minds born of cultivation.
In the form realm, there are no minds of craftsmanship.
The same is true for the formless realm.
It should be known that wholesome minds are also like this above and below.
They exist in all realms.
Moreover, there are distinctions in terms of the differences in seeds.
Namely, the desire realm has five kinds of minds.
First, a mind eliminated by seeing suffering.ğŸ”½Second, a mind eliminated by seeing the accumulation [of suffering].
Third, a mind eliminated by seeing cessation [of suffering].
Fourth, a mind eliminated by seeing the path [to cessation of suffering].
Fifth, the mind eliminated by the path of cultivation.
Just as there are five minds in the desire realm,
so too are there five minds in the form and formless realms, along with the undefiled mind.
In total, there are sixteen.
First, the meaning of the distinctions in the mind of different characteristics.
I will now analyze.
All sentient beings can be roughly divided into three categories.
The first is the category of those who have not yet set out on the path.
The second is the category of those who have already set out on the path but have not yet attained stability.
The third is the category of those who have already attained stability.
This is further divided into two types.
The first is impure.
The second is extremely pure.
In the first category, sometimes a defiled mind arises.
Because the mind is bound by afflictions such as greed.
Sometimes a wholesome or indeterminate mind arises.
Because afflictions such as greed are temporarily abandoned.
In the second category, sometimes the mind is inwardly calmed.
Sometimes due to forgetfulness, the mind runs towards the five sense pleasures and becomes scattered.
Sometimes due to extreme calmness,
the mind becomes covered by the afflictions of torpor and sleepiness.
Sometimes, in order to eliminate them,
one places the mind in a pure and wonderful object.
Sometimes, if the mind is not placed correctly, it becomes agitated.
If it is placed correctly, it does not become agitated.
Because the hindrances of sinking and agitation have not been eliminated,
in those two categories, the mind is not tranquil.
Because they have been eliminated, the mind attains tranquility.
If, by means of proper attention,
one has attained the fundamental meditative absorption,
it is called a concentrated mind.
If one has not attained it, it is called an unconcentrated mind.
Because it is the culmination of the path,
it is called a well-cultivated mind.
Because it is the culmination of elimination,
it is called an extremely liberated mind.
The opposite of this
is called an unwholesomely cultivated mind and an unliberated mind.
From the concentrated mind onward, it should be known as the third category.
This is called the distinction of the different characteristics of the aggregate of consciousness.
Next, what is the sequence of the aggregates?
It is said that this has five kinds of distinctions that should be known.
First, the sequence of arising.
Second, the function of counteracting.
Third, the function of transmigration.
Fourth, the function of abiding.
Fifth, the function of establishing.
As for the function of arising,
it refers to the eye and form as conditions being able to give rise to eye consciousness,
up to the mind and dharmas as conditions being able to give rise to mental consciousness.
Among them, the form aggregate is mentioned first, followed by the consciousness aggregate.
This is the basis of the mental factors.
Because the mental factors such as feeling arise based on it, it is mentioned next.
The sÅ«tra says that the three [aggregates] combine to form contact.
Contact conditions feeling, etc.
This is called the sequential explanation of the function of arising of the aggregates.
As for the function of counteracting,
in order to counteract the four inversions, the four establishments of mindfulness are taught.
Namely, the inversion of considering the impure to be pure,
the inversion of considering suffering to be happiness,ğŸ”½the inversion of considering non-self to be self,
and the inversion of considering the impermanent to be permanent.
Among them, the form aggregate is mentioned first,ğŸ”½followed by the feeling aggregate,
followed by the consciousness aggregate.
The two aggregates of perception and formation are explained later.
This is called the sequence of explanation according to the antidotes.ğŸ”½As for the sequence of explanation according to the process of cyclic existence,
the faculties and objects serve as the basis.
In the present life, the two aggregates experience objects and give rise to various defilements,
namely, experiencing objects and embellishing objects.
By means of the one aggregate, all wholesome and unwholesome actions are created.
In the future life, birth, aging, and so forth give rise to all defilements.
One is defiled, therefore it is explained last.
As for the sequence of explanation according to the process of abiding,
it is explained according to the four abodes of consciousness and the sequence of consciousness.
This is called the sequence of explanation according to the process of abiding.
As for the sequence of explanation according to the process of establishment,
when people in the world see each other, they first understand their form.
Therefore, the aggregate of form is established first.
Next, by means of the aggregate of feeling, one knows whether they are happy or suffering, advancing or retreating.
Therefore, the aggregate of feeling is established next.
Next, by means of the aggregate of perception, one knows their name, type, nature, and so forth.
Therefore, the aggregate of perception is established next.
Next, by the aggregate of formations, one knows that they are so foolish and so wise.
Therefore, the aggregate of formations is established next.
Later, by the aggregate of consciousness, the internal self is established.
That is to say, within the aggregates, the cognized is established as having suffering and having happiness.
Following the arising of speech and foolishness, etc.,
This is called the established function of the sequence of the aggregates' explanation.
Moreover, one should know the sequence of the aggregates' explanation based on the tools and affairs of the self.
That is to say, the body that the self relies on experiences suffering and happiness in regard to objects.
Following the arising of speech in regard to oneself and others,
Saying such and such a name, such and such a type, such and such a nature, etc.
These two kinds are only able to accumulate based on Dharma and non-Dharma.
In this way, one should know the affairs of the self's tools.
One should know that the last aggregate is the affairs of the self.
Next, how many aggregates, realms, bases, members of existence, bases and non-bases, and faculties are included in the aggregate of form?
The same applies to the aggregate of consciousness.
It means that the aggregate of form includes one aggregate in its entirety,
ten elements and ten sense bases in their entirety,
and a part of one element and one sense base.
It includes a part of six factors of existence,
and a part of the right and wrong bases.
It includes seven faculties in their entirety,
The aggregate of feeling includes one aggregate in its entirety,ğŸ”½and a part of one element and one sense base.
It includes one factor of existence in its entirety,ğŸ”½and a part of three factors of existence.
It includes a part of the right and wrong bases.
It includes five faculties in their entirety,
and a part of three faculties.ğŸ”½The aggregate of perception includes one aggregate in its entirety,
and a part of one element and one sense base.
It includes a part of three factors of existence,
and a part of the right and wrong bases.
It does not include any faculties.ğŸ”½The aggregate of volitional formations includes one aggregate in its entirety,
and a part of one element and one sense base.
It includes four factors of existence in their entirety,
and a part of five factors of existence.
It includes a part of the right and wrong bases.
It includes six faculties in their entirety,
and a part of three faculties.
The aggregate of consciousness includes one aggregate in its entirety,
and seven elements in their entirety,
One place is completely included.
One member is completely included.
Four members are partially included.
One part of the principle of proper and improper conditions is included.
One faculty is completely included.
Three faculties are partially included.
Thus there are six kinds of inclusion.
Namely, the inclusion of aggregates up to the inclusion of faculties.
By this principle of mutual inclusion,
One should understand the mutual inclusion as appropriate.
Moreover, there are ten kinds of inclusion that should be understood: First, the inclusion of realms,
Which refers to the aggregates, etc. being included in their own seeds.
Second, the inclusion of characteristics,
Which refers to the aggregates, etc. being included in their own specific and general characteristics.
Third, the inclusion of types,
Which refers to the aggregates, etc. being included in their own universal types.
Fourth, the inclusion of states,
Which refers to the aggregates, etc. being included in the states of being conducive to pleasant feeling, etc.
Fifth, the inclusion of inseparability,
Which refers to the aggregates, etc. being included by each dharma and its accompanying factors.
Sixth, the inclusion of time,
It means that the past, future, and present aggregates and so forth each include themselves.
Seventh, inclusion by direction.
It means that the aggregates and so forth that arise or depend on this direction are included in this direction.
Eighth, complete inclusion.
It means that the aggregates and so forth are included in the five and so forth.
Ninth, partial inclusion.
It means that the aggregates and so forth are included in each of their different parts.
Tenth, inclusion by ultimate meaning.
It means that the aggregates and so forth are included in the characteristics of suchness. In this way, the meaning of the total inclusion of all the aggregates has sixteen aspects.
Just as with the aggregates, so it is with the faculties.
Moreover, all dharmas are included in three dharmas.
Namely, the form aggregate, the dharma realm, and the mind base.
Next, in how many bases does the form aggregate arise?
In how many bases do the four aggregates that are included in name arise?
Namely, the form aggregate arises in six bases.
First, the established base.
Second, the concealed base.ğŸ”½Third, the equipment base.
Fourth, the faculty base.
Fifth, the dwelling base of the faculties.
Sixth, the place where the samÄdhi of majestic virtue is practiced.
Relying on seven places is called the transformation of the four aggregates that are included.
First, desire.
Second, hope.
Third, object.
Fourth, seeking and examining.
Fifth, right knowledge.
Sixth, pure skillful means.
Seventh, purity.
Those who enjoy desires
Rely on four places.
Those who abide in precepts and practice diligently
Rely on one place.
Those who have already attained the preliminary concentration
Rely on one place.
Those who abide in the fundamental concentration
Rely on one place.
Thus, these seven places are roughly divided into four categories, which should be known.
Next, I will first explain the individual meanings of the form aggregate.
Then I will distinguish the meanings of the four aggregates.
What is the distinction of the form aggregate?
The UdÄna says:
Substance, extreme subtlety, arising, establishment, and flowing activity
In a moment, unique activity, the rest mixed, and finally
Question: In the form aggregate, how many substances are included in the eye?
Answer: If according to mutual inclusion, there is only one substance.
Namely, the pure form that is the basis of eye consciousness.
If according to the inclusion of inseparability, there are seven substances.
Namely, this eye and the earth, form, smell, taste, and touch of the body.
If according to the inclusion of elements, there are ten substances.
Namely, these seven substances and the water, fire, and wind elements.
As for the ear, nose, tongue, and body, one should understand them in the same way.
The difference here is:
The pure form that is the basis of the ear and ear consciousness.ğŸ”½The pure form that is the basis of the nose and nose consciousness.
The pure form that is the basis of the tongue and tongue consciousness.
The rest is explained as before.
If it is the body, one should exclude the four such as the eye.
Why is it so?
Because they can be obtained separately from it.
This characteristic is the pure form that is the basis of body consciousness.
If it is the external form, smell, taste, and touch that they experience,
one should understand the rest in the same way as before, excluding all the faculties.
Because sound and the sound realm are not always present.
Now we will explain separately.
If there is sound in a certain place,
one should know that this place also increases by one.
One should know that the sound realm increases in all places.
Next, the objects of perception such as form,
have been extensively distinguished in the Abhidharma.
As for the derivative form spoken of in the category of tangibility, such as smoothness up to courage,
one should know that it is provisionally established based on the state of the primary elements.
That is to say, smoothness is provisionally established based on the pure nature of the primary elements.

Weight is provisionally established based on the solid nature of the primary elements.ğŸ”½Roughness and lightness are provisionally established based on the impure and non-solid nature of the primary elements.
Softness is provisionally established based on the impure and slow nature of the primary elements.
Cold is provisionally established due to the combination of water and wind.
Hunger, thirst, and weakness are provisionally established due to the lack of support and inequality.ğŸ”½Strength, fullness,
Illness is provisionally established due to the inequality and confusion of changes.
Aging is provisionally established due to the inequality of changes in time.
Death is provisionally established due to the inequality of changes in the life faculty.
Itching is provisionally established due to the inequality of blood disorders.
Fainting is provisionally established due to the inequality of bad food and drink.
Stickiness is provisionally established due to the arising of earth and water in combination.
Fatigue is provisionally established due to the inequality of weariness from coming and going.
If one is far from them, rest is provisionally established due to equality.
Vigor is provisionally established due to the removal of impurities and the avoidance of languor.
Thus, all the great elements are said to have six states in total.
Namely, the states of purity and impurity.ğŸ”½The states of solidity and non-solidity.
The slow state.
The combined state.
The unequal state.
The equal state.
These six states are further divided into eight.
Whether eight or six, they are equal in equality.
Furthermore, all forms up to tangibles
are cognized by two kinds of consciousnesses.
Namely, they are cognized by their own consciousnesses and by mental consciousness.
Either gradually or suddenly.
The five sense faculties such as the eyes are cognized by a single mental consciousness.
Furthermore, in the form realm there are no present smells and tastes, but there is that realm.
Why is it so?
Because both of them are included in the food of morsels.
Because of the absence of these two, the two consciousnesses of smell and taste also do not exist.
This is said in terms of their present operation, not in terms of their realms.
Thus, among all the forms included in the form aggregate,
nine kinds are real entities.
Among those included in tangibles, the four great elements are real entities.
You should know that the rest are only conventionally existent.
The form included in the dharma realm is also of two kinds.
Namely, real and conventional.
If it is the domain of practice by those with spiritual powers, like a transformation,
then the form that is the object of its fruit, its domain, and the consciousnesses associated with it, etc., are real entities.
If the form of moral discipline and the form of immorality both exist conventionally,
and if the form that is the object of meditation is bound to a realm,
then it is produced from the primary elements that bind it to that realm.
Moreover, this form of meditation is only mundane, contaminated or uncontaminated, and arises from meditation.
It is not supramundane, because this form of meditation has discursive thought and meditation as its cause.
Moreover, not all minds in meditation have the ability to produce this form.
Only one kind has the ability to produce it, like that which can create transformations.
That is, without reflection,
it is only drawn by previous attention.
Free from obscurity, extremely pure, and clearly present.
One should know that this meditation can produce form.
If the power of meditation repeatedly reflects,
and one sees it by the power of imagination,
one should know that it cannot produce this form.
Moreover, although this form is not the object of supramundane meditation,
there is one who can manifest it by the power of that meditation.
One should know that this matter is inconceivable.
Question: What is the difference between the real objects with form in the desire realm and form realm?
Answer: The forms in the form realm are pure and supreme, able to emit light.
Moreover, they are extremely subtle, not accessible to the faculties of lower realms. Therefore, they are free from suffering.
Based on those forms, painful feelings do not arise.
The desire realm is not like this.
This is the difference.
Furthermore, the form aggregate should be known in brief through six aspects.
First, its own characteristics.
Second, its common characteristics.
Third, the relationship between the support and the supported.
Fourth, the characteristics of experience.
Fifth, the characteristics of function.
Sixth, the subtle characteristics.
As for its own characteristics,
earth, etc. take solidity, etc. as their characteristics.
The eye, etc. take their respective pure forms as their characteristics.
As for its common characteristics,
all forms have the characteristic of being obstructive.
As for the relationship between the support and the supported,
the great elements are the support,
and the derivative form is the supported.
The characteristic of enjoyment is as follows:
Because there is the dominant power of the internal form sense base to be enjoyed,
The external form objects arise with distinctions.
In some form aggregates, only solidity arises,
In some only moisture, in some only heat,
In some only motion, in some a combination arises.
In order to accord with the distinctions in enjoyment of the internal form sense bases,
The characteristic of action is as follows:
It refers to the various great elements such as earth,
Whose characteristics are to support, to embrace, to mature, and to increase.
Other actions will be explained in detail later.ğŸ”½The subtle characteristic is as follows:
It refers to the characteristic of the most subtle particle.
Moreover, the subtle nature is roughly of three kinds:
The first is the subtle nature of reduction,
The second is the subtle nature of categories,
The third is the subtle nature of the mind freely turning.
The subtle nature of reduction is as follows:
It refers to analyzing forms to the most subtle state,
Which is called the most subtle particle.
The subtle nature of categories is as follows:
Namely, the form of wind and so forth, and the form of the intermediate state.
The subtle nature that arises from the transformation of the mind.
Namely, the form of the two realms of form and formlessness.
As the sutra says:
There are gods whose minds are equal.
Once in the human realm, they thus and thus nourish and polish their minds.
Following the power of this cultivation, they dwell in a place of empty space the size of a single hair tip.
They mutually obstruct each other.
Such groups should contemplate and observe the distinctions in the categories of the form aggregate.
Question: By how many kinds of characteristics should the form of the ultimate atom be established and understood?
Answer: In brief, by five kinds of characteristics.
If established in detail, as in the local divisions.
What are the five?
First, by discrimination.
Second, by distinction.
Third, by independence.
Fourth, by assisting companions.
Fifth, by being partless.
The establishment by discrimination.
Namely, by discriminating and discerning wisdom, one analyzes various forms.
The ultimate limit is established as the atom.
Not because of having a substance.
Therefore, the atom has no arising and no ceasing.
It is also not that form is composed of aggregated atoms.
As for the establishment of distinctions,
in brief, there are fifteen kinds of atoms.
Namely, there are five kinds of atoms of the eye and other faculties.
There are also five kinds of atoms of the objects such as form.
There are also four kinds of atoms of earth and so forth.
There is one atom of real substance included in the dharma realm.
As for the establishment of independence,
it is because the atom of substance establishes its own characteristics.
As for the establishment of companions,
it refers to the atom of aggregation.
Why is it so?
In the place of one atom of earth and so forth,
all the other atoms are gathered together in one place without separation.
Therefore, based on this, the atom of aggregation is established.
Why is it that the opposing dharmas are in the same place without separation,
but are not said to be without opposition?
Answer: Because they arise in accordance with each other.
Because they arise in accordance with each other without obstructing each other.
Moreover, such kinds of dharmas arise due to the dominant influence of such kinds of karma.
Why is this?
Because all aggregates of form are used in common by all faculties of form.
If it were otherwise,
in all aggregates there would be no form of earth, etc. that is inseparable.
If so, then the objects of the consciousnesses of the eye, etc.
would not be completely filled in all aggregates.
In this way there would be no complete enjoyment.
Therefore one should know that there are definitely forms that occupy the same place without separating from each other.
Moreover, there are formsğŸ”½that obstruct each other in some places,
and do not obstruct each other in some places.
Like the forms in the intermediate state, etc.
But those forms are not without resistance.
The principle here should be understood in the same way.
The establishment of the partless atom
It means that those atoms have no further divisions.
Because they are not aggregates.
All aggregates and atoms can have subtle divisions.
If the location of an atom is only that location,
there are no further subtle divisions that can be analyzed.
Question: As for these five characteristics of atoms that have been explained, there are also five eyes.
Namely, the flesh eye,
the heavenly eye,
the eye of holy wisdom,
the Dharma eye,
and the Buddha eye.
How many eyes are said to take all atoms as their objects?
Answer: It is said that except for the flesh eye and the heavenly eye, the remaining eyes take all atoms as their objects.
Why is it so?
Because that heavenly eye only takes the upper, lower, front, back, and two sides of the aggregate colors, if bright or dark.
It definitely cannot take the location of atoms.
Because the substance of atoms is established by the wisdom that analyzes them.
Question: Why is it said that atoms have no arising and no ceasing?
Answer: Because when all aggregate colors first arise, they arise completely.
When it finally perishes, it does not reach the state of an atom.
In the middle, it perishes completely, like a drop of water.
Moreover, by five aspects, one should know it as unreasonable to imagine an atom.
Namely, in a mass of form, there are atoms that exist by their own nature.
This should be known as the first unreasonable imagination of an atom.
Or, it is said that an atom has arising and perishing.
Or, it is said that an atom either combines with or disperses from another atom.ğŸ”½Or, it is said that various forms accumulate and abide in the amount of an atom.
Or, it is said that an atom can produce various masses of form.
This should be known as the latter unreasonable imagination of an atom.
Therefore, one should skillfully imagine an atom in a reasonable way.
Cut off these five kinds of unreasonable imaginations.
Moreover, establishing an atom should be known to have five kinds of benefits.
Namely, by the method of analyzing a mass of form,
one is able to purify and extensively cultivate the object of cognition.
This is the first benefit.
Moreover, one can gradually eliminate the view of the aggregates.
This is the second benefit.
Just as one can gradually eliminate the view of the aggregates,
in the same way one can also gradually eliminate pride.
This is the third benefit.
Moreover, one can gradually subdue the entanglements of the afflictions.
This is the fourth benefit.
Moreover, one can quickly eliminate various characteristics.
This is the fifth benefit.
One should contemplate in this way according to reason. Moreover, in brief, it should be known that there are five kinds of arising of material things.
What are the five?
First, arising based on support.
Second, arising from seeds.
Third, arising from impetus.
Fourth, arising from appropriation.
Fifth, arising from diminution.
What is arising based on support?
It refers to the arising of derivative form in the location of the primary elements that are the basis.
Therefore, it is said that the primary elements and the derivative form are included in the same place, in the sense of supporting them.
Moreover, if in this aggregate of form,
the intrinsic characteristics of those primary elements and derivative form can be obtained,
one should know that those dharmas exist here.
If in this place the intrinsic characteristics of those dharmas are completely unobtainable,
one should know that this place does not have those dharmas.
This is called the general establishment of the characteristics of existence and non-existence.
If someone says that in this place the intrinsic characteristics of those dharmas are unobtainable but they must exist,
one should now ask them:
Are the unobtainable and the obtainable
the same or not the same in substance?
If the substance is the same,
since the substance is the same but unobtainable,
it is unreasonable.
If it is not the same,
is it said to be not the same in substance based on this measure,
or is it said to be not the same in power?
If it is said to be not the same in substance based on this measure,
even a small part of the intrinsic characteristics would be unobtainable,
which is unreasonable.
If one speaks of unequaled power,
apart from their own characteristics, other powers cannot be obtained,
so it is not reasonable.
This kind of category should be known as arising from support.
What is arising from seeds?
All forms arise from their own seeds, like a solid mass.
Sometimes encountering conditions, it then gives rise to fluidity.ğŸ”½Fluidity encountering conditions again gives rise to solidity.
Heat gives rise to cold, and cold gives rise to heat.
Motionless gives rise to motion, and motion gives rise to motionless.
Good color, bad color, and so forth should be known in this way.
Because of this, although there are no characteristics, there are the realms.
From this and that aggregate, this and that form dharma arises with distinctions.
This kind of category should be known as arising from seeds.
What is arising from power?
It is because of the dominant power of the internal form faculties,
the external distinctions continue to arise.
It refers to the world of the vessel and so forth.
Moreover, it is because of the power of past karma that
the various internal forms arise with distinctions.
Moreover, for the various gods, whether their desires are present or not present,
and for the resources possessed by the people of Uttarakuru,
it should be understood that they arise with distinctions mainly due to the power of karma.
As for those who continue in the human realm, there is only the external world.
This kind of class should be known as arising from the power of karma.
What is arising from appropriation?
It means that due to encountering various conditions of appropriation,
various forms mutually increase and benefit, and arise in an excellent way.
Just like water moistening sprouts and so forth.
This kind of class is called arising from appropriation.
That which is contrary to this should be known as arising from loss.
Furthermore, when various aggregated forms arise,
like various substances ground into powder with a stone, mixed with water and rolled into a ball, they arise mixed together.
Not like the aggregates of sesame seeds, barley, beans, and so forth.
Why is it so?
It is because of the power of the dominant conditions of the causes of their arising.
Thus, it is born for the sake of having a function.
Question: If all conditioned forces are born from their own seeds,
why is it said that the primary elements produce derivative form?
Answer: Because when they transform, it transforms.
Because it is established by them and because it is supported by them.
For three reasons, when the primary elements transform, they cause derivative form to transform and change.
First, because of the function of a person.
Second, because of the work of karma.
Third, because of the power of samÄdhi.
As for the function of a person,
it means that because of being struck by the primary element earth,
because of the difference in the vessel,
and because of the difference in the field,
derivative form is caused to transform and can be obtained.
Or, because of being moistened by water, ripened by fire, and dried by wind,
derivative form is caused to transform and can be obtained.
You should know that this is called the transformation and birth of derivative form due to the transformation of those primary elements because of the function of a person.
As for the work of karma,
according to the power of karma, the primary elements are born first.
Later, according to their power, the color changes and arises.
This is called the result of karma.ğŸ”½Due to the power of samÄdhi,
the practitioner first gives rise to the great elements.
Then the derivative form changes and arises.
One should know that this is called the great elements changing due to the power of samÄdhi, and the derivative form arises due to this change.
Furthermore, in brief, there are five conditions by which the great elements cause the different fruits to transform into different fruits.
What are the five?
First, the power of the great elements.
Second, the power of human effort.
Third, the power of spells.
Fourth, the power of spiritual powers.
Fifth, the power of karma.
Question: After passing away from here,
what causes and conditions
cause the continuity of the form aggregate of the intermediate state to arise?
Answer: One should know that this form uses its own seeds as the cause
and the karma that induces birth as the condition.
Question: What causes and conditions are there for knowing that there is an intermediate state?
Answer: After passing away from here,
if there were no mind and mental factors without support,
Because it is not reasonable for it to move to another place.
It should not be like an echo, because it only deceives.
It should not be like a shadow, because it does not cease.
It should also not be said to be like the object of grasping.
Because it does not move by going.
Because of these and other such analogies,
it is not reasonable.
Therefore, one should know that there definitely is an intermediate existence.
In this way, one should contemplate the arising of the form aggregate. Furthermore, when the form aggregate arises, what is the foremost in terms of location?
Based on this location, do other forms arise?
One should know that the great elements are foremost in terms of location.
Later, other derivative forms arise based on this location.
Only the great elements are present in this location,
obstructing other derivative forms from completely filling it.
One should know that due to their power, there is something that is obstructed.
Furthermore, the four great elements such as earth,
should be known in order of their coarseness.
This refers to the earth element and its fruits.
It can hold the most excellent water, fire, wind, etc., and the functions of flowing, moistening, burning, shaking, etc.
It relies on them.
Therefore, it can be transformed.
Moreover, all sounds, as soon as they are uttered, are immediately cut off.
Therefore, they are not always continuous in a mass of form.
Moreover, when this sound arises in dependence on substance,
the substance and its location are both suddenly obtained.
According to the place where it is heard,
it arises everywhere in that place, like the light of a flame.
It does not gradually arise and gradually move forward.
Moreover, there are two kinds of wind:
continuous and discontinuous.
The wind that moves in circles is called continuous.
The wind that moves in the sky is called discontinuous.
The wind that moves in objects is called continuously accepted.
Moreover, you should know that the wind that operates the mechanism is called continuous.
The rest should be known as discontinuous.
What is called the space element?
Answer: Form that is included in light and darkness is called the space element.
This is also of two kinds.
One is always continuous.
The other is not always continuous.
If the dwelling places of sentient beings are always dark or always bright, it is called always continuous.
The other places are not so, and are not always continuous.
You should know that this is also based on a collection of form.
Moreover, this space element that is included in light is called pure.
That which is included in gaps and holes is called impure.
Question: As for the long, short, etc. shapes that are explained,
should they be said to truly exist or to exist as designations?
Answer: They should be said to exist as designations.
Why is it so?
Because they accumulate and abide, they are called shapes.
Only the accumulation of various forms can be obtained.
The characteristics of other shapes cannot be obtained.
Moreover, they must be mutually dependent.
If a dharma that is mutually dependent has its own nature,
then that dharma would have the fault of confusion.
Moreover, it is like a cart, etc.
Because that cognition can be destroyed.
Furthermore, among the dharmas included in the sphere of the mind, the results of meditation,
One should know that there are only the characteristics of visible form and so forth.
Why is this?
Because the causes for the arising of smells and so forth are lacking there.
And because they are useless.
In this way, in the wind moving in space,
there are no smells and so forth that arise together with it.
There are only those that are artificially combined.
Moreover, apart from the light emitted by the wheel,
the remaining primary elements and smells and so forth are all unobtainable.
Furthermore, the form that is included in the dharma realm and is the result of superior concentration,
one should know that this form only relies on superior concentration and does not rely on the primary elements.
However, because it arises from the samÄdhi that gives rise to images of that kind,
it is also said to be created by those primary elements.
It is not called created because it arises in dependence on them.
Question: Among the form aggregates, how many dharmas abide due to having form and obstruction?ğŸ”½How many dharmas abide due to not having form but having obstruction?
How many dharmas abide due to not having form and not having obstruction?
Answer: One abides by both kinds,
namely what is perceived by the eyes.
The rest only have obstruction.
Except for the form included in the dharma realm.
One should know that this form is invisible and unimpeded.
One should contemplate in this way the establishment of the form aggregate.
Next, by how many kinds of continuity does the form aggregate continue to evolve?
It is said to be by three kinds.
First, the continuity of natural outflow;
Second, the continuity of karmic retribution;
Third, the continuity of nourishment.
The first, the continuity of natural outflow, is of four kinds.ğŸ”½First, the continuity of karmic retribution and natural outflow;
Second, the continuity of nourishment and natural outflow;
Third, the continuity of transformation and natural outflow;
Fourth, the continuity of intrinsic nature and natural outflow.
The continuity of karmic retribution is also of two kinds.
First, the initial;
Second, the continuous.
It refers to the karmic retribution that arises from karma and the natural outflow produced by karmic retribution.
It refers to that which evolves later as karmic retribution, which is attracted by the power of that karma.
The continuity of nourishment is also of two kinds.
First, the continuity of nourishment that pervades widely;
Second, the continuity of nourishment that increases in appearance.
First, the stream of nourishment only nourishes form.
One should know that form is nourished by food, sleep, pure conduct, and meditative absorption.
The other streams of nourishment should be known as also due to food.
Because they are the basis of that.
Because of cultivating superior attention.
Because of long-term thorough ripening.
One attains nourishment.
All form dharmas are nourished by the two kinds of nourishment.
All formless dharmas are said to be nourished only by the increase of characteristics.
Moreover, form in the desire realm is nourished by the four foods and all other causes of nourishment.
The forms in the form realm are not nourished by coarse food, sleep, or pure conduct.
Moreover, it should be known that the form faculties are caused to flow by two kinds of streams.
Because the form faculties, apart from the continuity of karmic maturation and nourishment,
have no separate flowing stream outside of the continuity.
Question: Sometimes the continuity of karmic maturation also has increase and expansion.
Why is the flowing stream included in karmic maturation, but not in nourishment?
Answer: Because there is a separate continuity of nourishment that can embrace and uphold the karmic retribution and the outflow.
If the present increase, etc. are not included in the sense bases,
it should be known that they have three kinds of outflows.
All minds and mental factors have the outflow of the same kind, the outflow of karmic retribution, and the second outflow of nourishment that is nourished.
The form included in the dharma realm has no outflow of karmic retribution, and the rest should be known as the minds and mental factors.
Moreover, in the desire realm, internal and external forms are fully matured.
In the form realm, smell and taste are absent.
Moreover, in the desire realm, the maturity of the sense faculties may be complete or incomplete.
In the form realm, the faculties are necessarily complete.
Moreover, the sound realm also has karmic retribution, but sound does not.
One should contemplate the meaning of the outflows of the form aggregate in this way.
Next, how many functions does the earth element included in the form aggregate perform?
Up to how many functions does the wind element perform?
It should be known that all perform five functions.
Namely, the earth element can act as the function of striking, touching, and changing.ğŸ”½It acts as the function of establishing.
It acts as the function of providing support.
It acts as the function of harm.
It acts as the function of embracing.
The water element can act as the function of flowing and moistening.ğŸ”½It acts as the function of collecting.
It acts as the function of irrigating.
It acts as the function of harm.
It acts as the function of embracing.
The fire element can act as the function of illuminating.
It acts as the function of maturing.
It acts as the function of burning.
It acts as the function of harm. It acts as the function of embracing.
The wind element can act as the function of moving.
It acts as the function of following.
It acts as the function of drying up.
It acts as the function of harm.
It acts as the function of embracing.ğŸ”½Moreover, the great elements
should be known to be able to perform five functions with respect to the derivative form that they produce.
Namely, the function of giving rise.ğŸ”½The function of providing support.ğŸ”½The function of establishing.
The function of upholding.
The function of growth.ğŸ”½Because when they change and arise, they are able to lead the way.
Because when they change and arise, they are able to provide support by being inseparable from the place of those [derivative forms].
Because it can establish them by accepting their harm and sharing their safety and danger.
Because it can uphold them by maintaining their original measure and preventing their loss.
Because it can cause them to accumulate, progress, and expand.
Question: The good and bad forms that are the objects of the eyes and ears,
why do they become good and so forth, but not the other forms?
Answer: If explained briefly, it is due to the differences in the three kinds of volition, namely the soft, medium, and superior.
First, the volition of preparation;
second, the definite volition;
third, the volition that arises equally.
Because of this, if one is able to give rise to bodily and verbal manifest karma that is good or bad,
one should know that it is based on the superior volition that is able to give rise to good or bad karma.
Question: When there is movement based on the aggregate of form,
should it be said to be different from it or not different?
Answer: It should be said to be not different.
Why is it so?
If it were to arise or not arise, or to cease or not cease in that place, and yet there were movement,
there would be faults that could be found.
What are the faults?
If it is said that there is movement after arising, then it would violate the characteristic of a moment.
If it is said that there is no movement without arising, then there should be no movement.
If it is said that there is cessation, then it should be the same as the other [non-moving dharmas].
If it is said that there is no cessation, then it would violate the characteristic of movement.
Moreover, the causes and conditions for arising in a different place can be clearly obtained.
Therefore, one should know that there is no separate real substance of movement that can be obtained.
One should contemplate the activity of the form aggregate in this way and so forth.
Next, all form aggregates should be said to be characterized by momentary cessation.
Why is it so?
Because conditioned dharmas, as soon as they arise, are immediately destroyed.
This can be directly perceived.
Moreover, one should not say that the cause of arising is also the cause of cessation.
Because their characteristics are different.
Moreover, because no other cause of abiding can be found after a dharma has arisen.
Therefore, one should know that all conditioned dharmas cease spontaneously.
The meaning of momentariness is established by this principle.
If it is said that fire and so forth are the causes of destruction,
This is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
Because it is directly perceived that fire and so forth arise and cease together with those conditioned factors,
it is said that they have the function of serving as conditions for the arising of their transformation.
Moreover, it is unreasonable to say that destruction is the cause of destruction.
Why is it so?
Because it is unreasonable for them to arise together.
If destruction exists at the time of their arising,
then the fault of the complete destruction of the continuity would ensue.
Moreover, it is unreasonable to say that only the intrinsic nature of destruction is called cessation,
and that it is the cause of cessation.
If it is said that there is a separate intrinsic nature of destruction apart from those dharmas, and that it is the characteristic of cessation,
it is ultimately unobtainable,
so it is unreasonable.
If it is said that fire and so forth are the assisting companions of cessation and are thus able to cause cessation,
it is unobtainable in the spontaneous cessation of lamps, lightning, and so forth, as well as the mind and mental factors,
so it is unreasonable.
If you say that there is a separate function for each,
this distinction cannot be obtained,
so it is not reasonable.
If you say that the two kinds have the function of cessation in one place,
then the two kinds should both have the function of cessation in both parts, or they should have no function, because there is an error.
So it is not reasonable.
One should contemplate in this way the meaning of the momentary cessation of the form aggregate.
That is to say, because of the cause of spontaneous destruction,
in order to refute the view that fire, etc. are the cause of cessation,
in order to refute the view that the characteristic of cessation is the cause of cessation,
in order to refute the view that the two kinds are the cause of cessation,
one should understand all of this.
Moreover, because all conditioned forces are the result of mind,
one should know that like mind they all cease in a moment.
Next, as for derivative form in relation to the primary elements,ğŸ”½should it be said to have a different characteristic or
not have a different characteristic?
That is to say, it has a different characteristic.
Why is it so?
Because a different characteristic can be obtained.
The different characteristics here refer to:
That which is experienced by different faculties.
Why is this?
Because other material faculties can apprehend the primary elements.
And because other faculties apprehend derivative form.
Also, because of being able to be moved and not being able to be moved,
And because of being presently available.
This is because it is presently available in the world that the fragrance of various flowers can be moved and placed in sesame seeds.
But their solidity, etc. cannot be moved.
Also, because of being presently available as changing and not changing.
This is because in boiling ghee, etc., changes and distinctions in color, taste, etc. are available.
But their solidity, etc. are not.
Therefore, you should know that the primary elements and derivative form have different characteristics.
If you grasp as one that which has different characteristics,
Should it also be so for the primary elements?
Because the characteristics of the primary elements mutually differ from each other.
If you allow that,
Should there only be one primary element?
Therefore, one should know that all derivative form definitely has a different characteristic from the primary elements.
One should contemplate in this way the characteristics of primary elements and form as being unique or not unique.
Next, among the dharmas included in form,ğŸ”½how many are of the nature of faculties?
How many are of the nature of objects?
Five are of the nature of faculties.
Six are of the nature of objects.
What objects are the objects of the faculties?
If the faculties are not damaged, etc.
As extensively explained in the Basic Section.
That is to say, due to the basis,
or due to the characteristics,
or due to the direction,
or due to time,
or due to clarity or obscurity,
or due to the whole matter or a part of the matter.
By how many causes and conditions are the faculties said to be damaged or undamaged?
The answer is: by two causes and conditions.
First, due to weakness,
second, due to complete damage.
The opposite of this should be known as undamaged.
Moreover, in brief, the transformation of the faculties is due to four conditions.
First, arising from external conditions.
That is, due to the enjoyment and harm of external objects.
Or due to the benefit or harm of others.
Second, arising from internal conditions.
That is, due to the afflictions of greed, etc., produced by each individual improper attention.
Or due to the samÄdhi, etc., produced by proper attention.
Third, arising from karmic conditions.
That is, due to the power of the dominant condition of past karma, one receives a handsome or ugly appearance, etc.
Fourth, arising from the transformation of the essence itself.
That is, due to the differences in the specific characteristics of those faculties.
How many causes and conditions lead to the destruction of the mental faculty?
The answer is: due to four causes and conditions.
First, due to the hindrances.
That is, in the five hindrances, any one of the hindrances obscures the mind.
Second, due to distraction.
That is, due to ghosts and spirits disturbing the mind.
Third, due to what has not yet been realized.
It means that their inner mind has not yet realized the excellent qualities of the dhyÄnas and formless [absorptions].
However, they strongly apply their minds to them.
Fourth, by not yet understanding what is to be done.
It means that with regard to the affairs of much learning, craftsmanship, and so forth,
the mind is not yet fully mature and strongly applies skillful means.
How are the objects such as form, etc., in relation to those faculties called present? It means that form is neither conjoined, nor obscured, nor extremely subtle or distant to the eye.
It is also not obstructed and is called present.
Only when there is seeing, illumination, and no obstruction in a place that can be traversed is it called present.
Moreover, even though form is obscured and obstructed to the eye, it is still called present.
Sound is also necessarily neither conjoined, nor extremely subtle or distant to the ear faculty, and is called present.
Whether obstructed or unobstructed, whether illuminated or dark, in a place that can be traversed, it is all called present.
The three of smell, taste, and touch to the nose, tongue, and body,
only when conjoined can they be grasped in a place that can be traversed.
It is then called present.
The objects of activity.
If the divine eye only illuminates the visible, whether obstructed or unobstructed,
whether bright or dark, whether near or far,
it is all called present.
However, it is in a place where one can walk, not in a place where one cannot walk.
If the eye of holy wisdom, all kinds of form are all what is practiced.
Question: As the local division says, there are six kinds of practices.
What is the difference between these?
Answer: The first kind of practice.
Refers to form included in the world of sentient beings and form included in the world of the container.
The second kind of practice.
Refers to the three natures.ğŸ”½Because of the difference in nature.
Because of the difference in characteristics.
Because of the difference in function.
Because of the difference in state.
The difference in the characteristics of form.
Refers to blue, yellow, red, white, and so on, and so forth.
The difference in function.ğŸ”½Refers to the function included in the indicated and the non-indicated,ğŸ”½the precepts, the non-precepts,
and the neither-precepts-nor-non-precepts.
As for the distinction of states,
it refers to agreeable, disagreeable, and neutral objects.
As for the distinction of characteristics of sound,
it refers to sound caused by the great elements that are grasped,ğŸ”½sound caused by the great elements that are not grasped,
and sound caused by the great elements that are both grasped and not grasped.
As for the distinction of functions,
it refers to verbal expressions.
As for the distinction of states,
it should be understood as before.
As for the distinction of characteristics of smell,
it refers to the smells of roots, stems, bark, fruits, flowers, and leaves.
As for the distinction of functions,
it refers to the fact that smell, taste, and touch all have no function, and the distinction of states
should be understood as before.
As for the distinction of characteristics of taste,
it refers to sweet, bitter, and so forth, as already explained.
As for the distinction of characteristics of touch, it should also be understood as explained before in many ways.
The third type of objects of cognition refers to
the distinctions of directions such as southeast, northwest, etc.
The fourth type of objects of cognition should be understood as
the distinctions of past, future, and present.
Fifth, the nature of what is practiced.
It means grasping at the distinctions of real and unreal.
Sixth, the nature of what is practiced.
It means grasping at the distinctions of taking a part of an object or the entire object.
This kind of category is called the distinction of the manifestation of the objects of form. It should be known.
What is called the mental orientation that gives rise to [the objects of form]?
It is because the basis is not destroyed.
Because the objects manifest.
The mental factors that are produced can lead to the mind.
One should contemplate in this way the characteristics of the objects of the aggregate of form.
Furthermore, those in the desire realm rely on the body of the desire realm.
They give rise to the great elements of the form realm.
Those great elements manifest.
How do they coexist with the form of the lower realm?
Are they in different places or not in different places?
It should be said that it is like water and sand, not coexisting in different places.
In this way, one should contemplate how the aggregate of form coexists in mutual mixture.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Discourse on the Stages of Concentration Practice, Scroll 54
